p: The report has four categories, each appearing as a subtab in the report.
This tutorial describes the Appellate History category, which contains direct and indirect case history treatment regarding your case.
You can view the appellate history as a List or a Map. Map view provides a graphical representation of the relationships between the items in the appellate history.

section.title: Appellate History List

i.#tail: ®, and shows its prior and subsequent appellate history.

p.#text: The Appellate History list highlights the citation you

p: The "subsequent appellate history" link lets you jump directly to that portion of the list.
Prior and subsequent appellate history are presented in an "outline" format, where indentations are used to identify the direct relationships between the listed cases.
The "Show on map" link lets you jump to the case's location on the appellate history map.

Color-coded icons tell you the signal-generating value of the editorial phrase to the right of the icon. Hover on an icon to display it's meaning. You also can select the Legend button to display descriptions of all symbols used in the report.

section.title: Appellate History Map

p.#text: This is a graphical representation of your

p: Each item on the map represents a case.  These points correspond to the cases on the Appellate History list.
The levels tell you which court made each ruling.
You can hover on a case to display the full editorial phrase.

Click its icon to highlight a case and display more information about it.  The information box also provides links that let you open the document  or jump to the document's location in the appellate history list.
